479. Dowling Jemima McKenzie (Mrs. William)
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A NOTE OF EXPLANATION TO THE PERSON ANSWERING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences or those of your parents. If you answer "no" to any question, do not worry about answering others. It is better to be truthful or to leave the questionnaire blank than to answer the questions incorrectly or dishonestly.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1911, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Western Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Past: What Did We Do?" would also be useful if it is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Provincial Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

Dowling, Jemima McKenzie (Mrs. Wm. M.)
Box 123, MacDowell.

To Sask., October, 1888
Darling, Jemima McKenzie (Mrs. William)
Box 125, MacDorell.

To Sask. - October, 1894

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES
No. 2
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Jemima McKenzie
2. Your address: East Williams, Ontario
3. Date: Oct. 1894
4. What was your father's name and occupation? Farmer
5. When did you come to Saskatchewan? Oct. 1894
6. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
7. How did you learn about the West? Through other people? Reading about it?

"I came with my husband by his consent."

At Frank Grace.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? With anxiety, I heard for my safety, coming soon after the land settlement.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other groups)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

The came by train to Qu'Appelle, from there to Fort Qu'Appelle, with our oxen, carrying the trail where most were lost from Qu'Appelle to Prince Albert.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

We came in a boat and had to cross the river several times. We met many Indians along the way, some friendly, others not so friendly. We also met a group of settlers who were very helpful.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

In our tent, once we moved back to the homestead.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We came to Medicine Hat in 1876 with our children, where we lived on a rented farm for 8 years. We then bought a place in Dewdney.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

By working for farmers in Saskatoon, B.C.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience if those days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount? In 1902 there was an epidemic of diphtheria around Prince Albert. Many children died. We lost a boy of 9 to a child of 79 months. For 6 weeks our clothes were on the gold panning clothes line to dry, as a driving rainstorm forced us inside.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel? What was the cost of fuel and so forth? How much did you pay for every time we got together to read a hymn or a travelling story? The Bible very young. Occasionally a travelling minister would come and we would enjoy his stories. Traveling ministers.
25. When was the first car used in the community?

26. If you owned a car before 1911, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? About 50 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate those war transactions. Your total purchases were by mail.

While honestly we did practically all our buying by mail, we purchased much hardware, groceries, etc., from the mail order catalogs.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Gladewaterman the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
5.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My husband was active in The Church Board.

School Board. I have been a member of the Board for many years.

When we moved to the new school, I attended the opening ceremony.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were actively engaged in anything in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizations, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) date of its adoption (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in name since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of how name is above in (1) (2) (3).

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, family papers and photographs, minutes books of community organizations, old newspapers, reminiscences, oral traditions, recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Would you or the person who owns them either:

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?
